citation.article-title: Legionella cincinnatiensis sp. nov. isolated from a patient with pneumonia.

p.s: Description of Legionella cincinnatiensis sp. nov.
Legionella cincinnatiensis (cin.cin.na.ti.en'sis. N. L. fem. adj. cincinnatiensis coming from Cincinnati, Ohio)
Legionella cincinnatiensis is a gram-negative, flagellated rod with predominately branched-chain cellular fatty acids.
It is positive in reactions for catalase, gelatinase, and browning of tyrosine-supplemented agar and requires cysteine for growth.
It is negative in reactions for urease, hydrolysis of hippurate, reduction of nitrate to nitrite, and acid production from D-glucose.
It can be identified serologically in the slide agglutination test with absorbed antiserum.
The type strain of L. cincinnatiensis is 72-OH-H (ATCC 43753), which has a G+C content of 36.3 mol%.
It was isolated from human lung tissue.
